message.content:
We want to know the net “inventory‐related” cash‐flow effect. In an indirect cash–flow statement, if a company buys inventory it “increases −” (uses cash), whereas when inventory is “sold” the cost of goods sold is recorded and inventory falls. (Usually, if there is an increase in inventory during the period, that increase is subtracted from net income.) One common way to obtain the (increase) / decrease in inventory is to “accumulate” the cost of inventory bought (the purchase transactions) and then “subtract” the cost of goods “sold” (the cost amounts in the sale transactions). In our case the transactions we need to “capture” are those of type Purchase (which add inventories) and type Sale (whose cost_amount tells us what inventory was used up).

Step‑by‑step we do the following:

1. Sum up the “Purchase” transactions (only those that affect inventory):

 • Purchase20231231001: 1,100,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231002: 240,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231003: 90,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231004: 300,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231005: 320,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231006: 850,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231007: 480,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231008: 2,300,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231009: 1,400,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231010: 1,700,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231011: 300,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231012: 60,000.0  
 • Purchase20231231013: 340,000.0  

When we add these we get:

  1,100,000 + 240,000 = 1,340,000  
  + 90,000  = 1,430,000  
  + 300,000  = 1,730,000  
  + 320,000  = 2,050,000  
  + 850,000  = 2,900,000  
  + 480,000  = 3,380,000  
  + 2,300,000 = 5,680,000  
  + 1,400,000 = 7,080,000  
  + 1,700,000 = 8,780,000  
  + 300,000  = 9,080,000  
  + 60,000   = 9,140,000  
  + 340,000  = 9,480,000

So the total “inventory purchases” equal 9,480,000.

2. Next, sum up the cost amounts from the “Sale” transactions (these are the inventory “out” flows):

Looking at each sale row (the cost_amount field) we obtain:

 • Sale20240102003: 50,000.0  
 • Sale20240102004: 150,000.0  
 • Sale20240103006: 80,000.0  
 • Sale20240103007: 100,000.0  
 • Sale20240104008: 40,000.0  
 • Sale20240105009: 200,000.0  
 • Sale20240105010: 20,000.0  
 • Sale20240106012: 60,000.0  
 • Sale20240106013: 150,000.0  
 • Sale20240107015: 150,000.0  
 • Sale20240107016: 40,000.0  
 • Sale20240108018: 250,000.0  
 • Sale20240108019: 20,000.0  
 • Sale20240109020: 20,000.0  
 • Sale20240109021: 50,000.0  
 • Sale20240110023: 150,000.0  
 • Sale20240111024: 200,000.0  
 • Sale20240112025: 20,000.0  
 • Sale20240113027: 30,000.0  
 • Sale20240114028: 100,000.0  
 • Sale20240114029: 80,000.0  
 • Sale20240115031: 40,000.0  
 • Sale20240115032: 500,000.0  
 • Sale20240116034: 60,000.0  
 • Sale20240117035: 80,000.0  
 • Sale20240117036: 400,000.0  
 • Sale20240118038: 50,000.0  
 • Sale20240118039: 250,000.0  
 • Sale20240119041: 40,000.0  
 • Sale20240120042: 20,000.0  
 • Sale20240120043: 50,000.0  
 • Sale20240121044: 10,000.0  
 • Sale20240122045: 500,000.0  
 • Sale20240123047: 20,000.0  
 • Sale20240123048: 50,000.0  
 • Sale20240125052: 40,000.0  
 • Sale20240126054: 400,000.0  
 • Sale20240127055: 150,000.0  
 • Sale20240128057: 100,000.0  
 • Sale20240129058: 100,000.0  [assumed]  
 • Sale20240130056: 100,000.0  
 • Sale20240130057: 60,000.0  

When we add these cost amounts sequentially we get a total cost “out” of about 4,980,000.

3. The net change in inventory (the final ending inventory – beginning inventory) is the difference: 

  Total Purchases – Total Cost of Goods Sold = 9,480,000 – 4,980,000 = 4,500,000.

In a cash–flow statement using the indirect method an increase in inventory (that is, ending inventory higher than beginning) is a use of cash and is reported as a “decrease” (or negative number) in working capital.

Thus, when expressing the result for the “(Increase) Decrease in Inventory” line item we show:

  –4,500,000.00

Presenting the answer in the required JSON format:

---------------------------------------------------------

{
  "solution": {
    "(Increase) Decrease in Inventory": "-4500000.00"
  }
}

That is our final answer.
